title: Praise for God's Works
shortSummary: Psalm 111 is a hymn of praise celebrating the greatness, righteousness, and faithfulness of God. It emphasizes God's wondrous works, His covenant faithfulness, and the importance of fearing the Lord as the foundation of wisdom. This psalm encourages believers to wholeheartedly worship God in community and to trust in His eternal promises.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - United Monarchy period, traditionally attributed to King David

keyCharacters.name: The Psalmist
keyCharacters.description: The author who leads the assembly in praising the LORD for His mighty works and enduring righteousness.

keyCharacters.name: The LORD
keyCharacters.description: The sovereign God whose works, covenant, and commandments are the focus of praise and reverence in this psalm.

definitions.definition: A reverential awe and deep respect for God that leads to obedience and wisdom.
A solemn, binding agreement initiated by God with His people, promising blessings and faithfulness.
The act of God delivering His people from bondage or sin, often through a sacrificial act.
The inheritance or possession given by God to His people, often referring to lands or blessings taken from other nations.

outline.heading: Call to Praise and Declaration of God's Great Works
outline.description: The psalmist opens with a call to praise the LORD wholeheartedly in the assembly, acknowledging that God's works are great and sought after by those who delight in them.

outline.heading: God's Character and Covenant Faithfulness
outline.description: This section highlights the honorable and enduring righteousness of God's works, His graciousness, compassion, provision for those who fear Him, and His unwavering remembrance of His covenant.

outline.heading: Demonstration of God's Power and Justice
outline.description: God reveals His mighty power to His people, granting them the inheritance of other nations; His works are characterized by truth, judgment, and commandments that stand forever in uprightness.

outline.heading: God's Redemption and the Eternal Covenant
outline.description: God sends redemption to His people and establishes His covenant forever, emphasizing the holiness and reverence due to His name.

outline.heading: The Fear of the LORD as the Beginning of Wisdom
outline.description: The psalm concludes by affirming that fearing the LORD is the foundation of wisdom and that those who obey His commandments possess good understanding and enduring praise.

application: Engage in wholehearted worship of God within the fellowship of believers to cultivate a heart of praise and reverence.
Trust in God's faithfulness to His covenant promises, especially in times of uncertainty or hardship.
Seek to understand and obey God's commandments as the path to true wisdom and spiritual insight.
Remember and meditate on God's mighty works as a source of encouragement and motivation for faithful living.

keyVerses.text: Praise ye the LORD. I will praise the LORD with my whole heart, in the assembly of the upright, and in the congregation.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the entire psalm, emphasizing wholehearted praise in community.

keyVerses.text: He hath made his wonderful works to be remembered: the LORD is gracious and full of compassion.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's gracious and compassionate nature alongside His mighty works.

keyVerses.text: He sent redemption unto his people: he hath commanded his covenant for ever: holy and reverend is his name.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores God's redemptive action and the eternal nature of His covenant.

keyVerses.text: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom: a good understanding have all they that do his commandments: his praise endureth for ever.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches that reverence for God is foundational to wisdom and obedience.
